(First in a series on the current Italian political scene)*
This is Graham Hovey, recording in Home a radio Letter from Italy for the national
Association of Educational Broadcasters — the BABB Network.
As I record these lines, the government of Italy, headed by Mario Soelbs as prime
minister, has just won its fourth parliamentary vote of confidence in as many weeks.
On none of those four occasions was the Scelba government in serious danger of being
turned out of office. Three of the four votes — one in the senate and two in the chamber
of deputies — gave Signor Scelba his biggest majorities since he formed his cabinet last
February 10*
Those were not whopping majorities, to be sure. The party lineups in both chamber
and senate since the national elections of 1953 make it impossible for any middle-road
Italian government to count on comfortable margins, "hen the democratic parties backing
the Scelba government can keep their ranks intact to a man they can muster sure majorities
of only eight votes in the chamber and six in the senate.
In its least impressive showing in the four votes of confidence I have cited, the
Scelba government had a margin of 17 votes in a senate of 237 members. And in each of its
teats in the chamber, the government mustered 30 more votes than its combined opposition
of political left and right.
This meant that the four parties supporting the government had kept their lines in tact |
that when the chips were down, the democratic coalition rebuilt by Signor Scelba under
difficult circumstances nine months ago could still hang together and permit the government
to funotion.
Thus, these four confidence votes should have been what the term implies» they should
have bolstered the confidence of both government and country! they should have constituted
entries on the credit aid© of the ledger for middle-road, democratic government.
This should have been true especially because two of those confidence votes directly
concerned the settlement, at last, of the Trieste question, which is deeply felt by nearly
all Italians.
It is true that few Italians are entirely satisfied with the settlement, which leaves
so much of Istria and many Italian nationals under Yugoslav rule. But I think most Italians
concede that the settlement was the best Italy could hope for under present circumstances.
Thus, the government had every right to hope that the return to Italy of the Adriatic
port city would be regarded as a victory for the course of patienoe and firmness which it
has followed. And this victory oould hardly fail to embarrass the governments critics of
the Communist-dominated left and the neo-Fasoiet and ultra-nationalist right.
The tub-thumpers of the political right were oonfrented with the hard fact that quiet,
patient diplomacy had achieved something that the street riots end tough talk and bellicose
postures of a year ago oould not achieve.
As for the Communists, their position on Trieste had long ago become ludicrous, because
